body: His sightless eyes horribly watch the air;Of observation lying on the groundAnd trumpet at his lips; nor does he castYes. You'd want that said, (if youToward the still dab of white that oscillatesBeyond ice floe and berg and ice-bound sea,That rings, with faithful tongue, its pious noteClose at the end of distance the two ChoseThe weight of being born into exile is lifted.Not so much of place as of renewed hope,A matter of getting all that right .  .Snow haze gleams like sand.will come, blighting our harbingers of spring,For any part of them we can make outThey move against, or through, or by, or toward.Will hear the storm-blast of his clarion.their bellies, they're out cold, instantaneouslyGray the cloud-like oaks—Now that you notice it—have just moved past
